Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Aspherical Nature and Evolution of Supernovae
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support a long-term comprehensive spectropolarimetric survey of all types of supernovae. The principal goal of this effort is to improve the understanding of the characteristics and importance of asymmetries in supernova explosions by focusing on the observable evolution. Polarimetry allows one to probe spatial scales in a supernova that cannot be resolved through direct imaging from earth or space. Spectropolarimetry further enhances the power of this technique by revealing wavelength dependent variations that may result from optical depth dependent geometries. In recent years, evidence has grown that nearly all supernovae exhibit departures from spherical symmetry. These results, together with advances in computing power that enable full three dimensional modeling, are exposing the possibility that asymmetries are not just observable consequences of supernovae, but may in fact be a necessity of the explosion mechanism itself. The investigators will obtain repeat spectropolarimetry of the brightest core collapse and thermonuclear. These data will be augmented with both photometry and high-resolution spectroscopy.

The project is expected to have an impact on astrophysics as the diagnostic power of polarimetry continues to advance, especially in the era of giant telescopes and time-variable astronomy. This project will also support a number of outreach and education efforts at each institution and will contribute to the education and training of undergraduate and graduate students. In addition, Dr. Hoffman will continue her leadership of the Collaborative Research in Astrophysics (CORA) program at the University of Denver. This program is based on studies that show that participation in group research projects increases retention of female students in scientifically and technically demanding majors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of this project was to study the nature of asymmetries in supernova explosions and how they evolve with time. This was achieved through a systematic observing campaign using three different telescopes that exploited the nature of the supernova light after it has scattered out of the expanding atmosphere of the explosion. For spherical explosions, there is no preferred orientation for the integrated light.  However, for non-spherical explosions, there is a small, but measurable preferred orientation.  We use a technique called polarimetry to measure any preferred orientation, i.e. the polarization.  We gain additional insight by measuring this polarization as a function of wavelength.  Wavelength dependent variations can shed light on the depth of the asymmetries and how they evolve.

Our goal was to observe at least 15 supernovae over three years and follow their evolution with observations during multiple epochs.  We far exceeded our goal; during the period of funding, we've observed 79 different SNe of all types. Of those, 59 (74%) were observed at multiple epochs; 21 of these were observed twice and 38 (48% of the total sample) were observed at three or more epochs. We've found that more than half of the supernovae we've observed show some evidence of intrinsic polarization suggesting that the majority of all supernovae are non-spherical.

We created a website (http://grb.mmto.arizona.edu/~ggwilli/snspol/) that describes the goals and strategies of the project and provides information about all our observations and links to our publications. We've published five refereed papers on individual supernovae and have several others near submission.  We've also presented our results through talks and posters at multiple conferences.  We've provided public lectures about this work to several groups and have developed a hands-on demonstration of the techniques used for the project for public outreach purposes.

As part of this research, eight graduate students were trained in various aspects of spectroscopy, photometry, spectropolarimetry, and modeling.
